answers.answer: Whether he's diabetic or not depend on the blood glucose levels.  Anxiety doesn't cause diabetes, but it can lead to behaviors that do, such as eating the wrong foods (simple carbs, sugar, alcohol).  Anxiety isn't genetic as far as anyone has proven, but diabetes can be.  Now, you live in India, which has this great tradition of meditation, yoga, and Ayurveda.  Have you investigated any of these?  They teach great coping mechanisms for people who don't adapt well to stress, and are used frequently in other parts of the world by therapists to help people with this problem.

I agree with Paxiled's post 100%.Anxiety can not CAUSE diabetes, but its symptoms can exacerbate its symptoms and complications.  Also, sometimes it can be difficult to determine if symptoms are a result of diabetic issues (ie hypo/hyperglycemia) versus anxiety.  Someone having a panic attack can present with a lot of the same symptoms, and in reverse, hypo/hyperglycemic episodes can cause or exacerbate anxiety.It's important that BOTH conditions be as well managed as possible.
